comments.commentBody:
It's been a VIAL I know, but I like to BOOST of the fact IRAN a MILO RACE in under six and a half minutes, ONCE around the Central Park Reservoir back in the SEVENTies!
Of course, that was DIN, nowadays it would be the top of the NEWS here in Quincy, If I could go out to the MALEbox and back in that same time!
OKAY, so I'm not too swift afoot anymore, however, I like to fancy, at least second story-wise, that I still GAZA GOLAN on here in WP! LOL

Howie TBoQ

Unfortunately the wheels of media are greased by advertising revenue first and foremost - don't want to offend the advertisers, or the advertisers' customers.
Secondly, the majority of those billed as "financial journalists" don't know much about finance, economics, law or business. A handful of undergraduate courses was enough to confirm my suspicions that reporters generally regurgitate press releases published by those they write about.
Keep in mind, who owns the media. Their goal is not necessarily to inform, let alone investigate, as was once the case, but to make more money.

A success, but a partial one. The fact that no high level Wall Street officials involved in the global financial crisis have been indicted and convicted renders any claim of full success flawed. We also learned during the audit that Bernie Sanders and others pushed for that the Federal Reserve Bank lent and spent to the tune of many TRILLIONS of dollars to keep the financial system afloat, beginning BEFORE things fell apart in the fall of 2008.

What I really wish our media, including the New York Times, would do, for the sake of the American public, is tell the truth about all of this. Instead, we get half-stories, he said/she said accounts, and the general impression that not only has President Obama been a middling failure, but that things resolved themselves mostly according to "free market" principles, when the reality of necessary government intervention prevented the worst global economic depression ever.

We get the truth from you, but what about the rest of the US media?
Yes, in the scheme of eternity they are profoundly stupid.  They forget that actions have consequences, and flim flam is useless at the end.

The idea that you think either the health care system or the banking system were working just fine and required no new regulations is curious, to say the least.  Health care and financial systems are both large and complex, so laws to reform them will also be large and complex.  Are these perfect reforms?  By no means.  But are they an improvement over what went before?  Of course they are. And the fact that the Republicans didn't support the health care reforms, even when the proposed system was modeled on a Heritage foundation created idea and implemented successfully by a Republican governor in Massachusetts is yet another piece of evidence that Republicans made a conscious decision to oppose any initiatives by President Obama, even if such initiatives were based on Republican ideas.  It would be laughable if real people's lives were not at stake.  So no, you can't use the lack of Republican support to argue against these laws.

"Calling the ACA a failure or a success at this point is arrogant and premature," . . . [but] "Frankly, I think Obamacare as it stands is an absolute mess."

"We'll just have to wait and see, which is something fewer and fewer people are able to do."

You can't possibly be serious...? If you are an engineer as your name implies, then you should know that a woman's ability to excel in science is in no way affected by her "style, makeup, walking straight, standing up straight." Why in the world should girls be subjected to sexist, superficial teachings instead of giving them real skills to succeed in life?
It would be worse for the commenters to tell her that she IS physically  beautiful. One should never rely on something  so ephemeral and subject to public opinion for power and strength.
Sorry, that's a libertarian fantasy.  Even the most conscientious parents are being overwhelmed.  You might as well claim the local PTA can go toe to toe politically with the Koch brothers.

YouTube is a Lawless wasteland which is largely operated by Interns. Videos of Teenage girls are enough to Sue the site as they are allowing underage children to become abused by cruel (most likely Male) and bored users.

YouTube, like Facebook, is waning in its popularity and it will eventually go away. I hope that other Video sharing sites will refrain from allowing Videos of this type to be posted to their sites.

No they're not. Not if parents monitor their kids' use of electronics. It's not hard. Get a keylogger and tell the kids they can have devices without keyloggers when they're ready to pay for them themselves. Not if schools, churches, synagogues, and mosques take a strong stance againt this. And especially not if girls -- and this is a girl thing, let's not call it anything else -- take a strong stance against it with other girls. It's amazing how quickly how many kids stand willing to call a peer, but not a practice, ugly.

Absolutely astounding.  How in heaven can our own Congress get away with something like that with so little press around it?  Honestly, this is the first I've heard of it and   it makes my blood boil.  If ever there were more convincing proof that they are all bought I can't imagine what it would be.

A healthy socio-political system cannot perceive an utmost
exploitation of the guy at the receiving end as a virtue.
Even if some relative improvement happens (Frank – Dodd,
Affordable Health Care) still the overall exploitive principle is
in pursuit.

The financial cartel, legal cartel, big pharma/medical
cartel, higher education cartel are very powerful entities
set to take fruits of hard labour from the toiler who is
treated more and more as a serf. They call if freedom.
But they offer freedoom instead (this is not misspelling).

When I am looking around there is no even one
country which follows similar pattern…
Ask yourself question why…

My friend returned from Florida to Canada after having
broken her arm, financially broken, when paying $ 35000
for a relatively trivial procedure. Such a robbery cannot
happen anywhere…, but in my beloved America…

The orgy of corruption that is the entire United States Congress and President is summed up by this touching story.

In November 2011, 60 Minutes did an expose on insider trading within Congress.

While normal Americans have been subject to basic insider trading rules since the 1934 Securities Exchange Act, members of Congress were "inexplicably" exempt from the rules.

Congressmen have access to market-moving, non-public information and make use of it to make lots of money.

After that 60 minutes report came out, Congress - out of self-preservation - passed the STOCK (Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge) Act in record fashion in 2012 with overwhelming bipartisan support to make insider trading laws that apply to Congress and Congressional staffers for the first time.

One year later in 2013, some of the details of the ban on insider trading were beginning to chafe Congressional staffers, who found it hard to pad their income with some friendly trades on insider knowledge.

So Congress quietly rolled back a big part of the law in April 2013 -the part that required staffers to post disclosures about their financial transactions, so that the public could make sure there was no insider trading going on.

Congress did the whole thing quietly by unanimous voice vote with no debate and no names attached to it, the Senate approved it and President Obama signed it into law.

Dodd-Frank is a similar product of a hopelessly corrupt, sociopathic and ethically dead Congress.

That's right. We cannot let the "point and laugh " reactions to progressives by the mainstream media define and limit us. So , Teachout's campaign is " tilting at windmills" ? What about actual voters and what they prioritize ? We know today's democracy is limited by candidates' access to advertising $$s and also that big money brings credibility to skeptical reporters . Ginia Bellafante's column demonstrates that.
As Ed Koch once said: "If you don't like it....MOVE".
I 'heart' NYC!  Give me the gnar, Charing Cross never had the human tide of flotsam and jetsam we endure, Give me the Gnar!  The haters can stay entombed in their suburban oases.
Yeah, the city really has gone downhill. Bring back the bankrupt seventies and the porn shops in Times Square.
James, you should read the Constitution to learn how the legislative process works.  Unless the Republicans take 67 seats in the Senate,  there will be no repeal of ACA or Dodd-Frank.

Nick,

Thank you. "repeal" is too strong of a word. I should have said "amend". GOP donors are not happy with the lack of vigor by the GOP in changing the ACA. I have listened to the debate over about 45 votes in the House to "repeal" the ACA. It seems to me that many are sincerely worried that the U.S. is sinking into socialism.

Dr. K,

You are correct, the ACA and the Dodd-Frank are significant achievements of a Democratic Congress. They provide the foundation for even greater social & economic progress. However, I think when you consider what has happened since the 2010 elections, it causes one to project that the progress can NOT be sustained. Certainly, if the American people elect a Republican majority in both bodies of Congress, I suspect that the ACA will be repealed & replaced with a more insurance & medical industrial complex friendly system underscored by a rhetorical rationale that free enterprise, free and open competition our healthcare will bring back the economic approach that has made America exceptional and the richest country in the World. Even though there will always be sticky wickets on the distribution of income.

The financial institution story will be slightly different but there will be a requirement to restore the global competitiveness of our banks and investment houses. I also anticipate a change in treatment of retirement savings and pension funds so that competing free enterprise systems will gradually replace our social security and disability retirement programs.

Mr. Ryan believes that the programs are incentivizing people to avoid work. He says disability and other safety net programs are causing people to not want to work. He says that pay from an honest day's work is so low that most consider staying on the dole.

We will see how America feels on Nov.4.

Really? That's all you can think? Perhaps that's how it looks from 3000 miles away but I live in NY and have to commute for 1.5 hours each way because real estate is so expensive. So I find it interesting any time I see more housing being built. It's a good thing that these parts of the city are being reclaimed for housing. Maybe if enough housing goes in, prices will allow me to move somewhere closer to where I work so that I don't have to spend 3 hours a day commuting.
New York is basically finished. Time to move from Rome to Byzantium, wherever that is.

We've had a small apartment on 14th St. for 30+ years. It's in what was then a pretty seedy block, and yes it is still noisy (noise-resisting interior windows, when we could afford them, make a huge difference). The convenience of the location, close to Union Square, FAR outweighs the disadvantages, and we're not in a modern luxury building that the article is touting. It's a great location, and no longer seedy. I say to the up-and-coming (not the self-congratulatory yuppies): Find and buy that apartment in an old building on 14th St., and fix it up!
News would be made only if a Marvel movie FAILED to make a killing at the box-office. How much is Stan Lee worth right now anyway?

"If you cut pensions, you cut the spine of all the people who worked for peanuts compared to private industry. Soon no one will want a job working for any municipality."

Wow, seriously? You have to do some simple research, and then come back and tell us public workers have it so bad. I'm afraid you have a serious misconception about those salaries, and, on top of those healthy wages, the fantastic benefits like said pensions, time off, and, most important, job security. I would guess that a large majority of New Yorkers who are working for near minimum wages in many private businesses would be very happy with such a job.

The "worked for peanuts compared to private industry" is a pretty tired old excuse that might have been true decades ago but no longer.  When you add in benefits, job protections, etc., the idea that government workers are down trodden and living hand to mouth in comparison with the private sector is just not valid.
How do you know?

So was this a story about pensions or just another dig on deBlasio and another tribute to a mayor who couldn't give a fig about the working middle class?
Every city pension is handled differently and invested differently. And not all city pensions should be labeled "strained". Many contracts now call for higher contributions by employees as well as contributing to health care. And if that money is invested wisely and with firms that have good reputations, that's 30 years of interest being reinvested.

But honestly you cannot report that deBlasio is not interested just because he doesn't mention it in speeches. If you cut pensions, you cut the spine of all the people who worked for peanuts compared to private industry. Soon no one will want a job working for any municipality.

From a religious experience I had following 3 years in a concentration camp I came away with the understanding we all, each one of us, was part of All and All was love. There is no separation between me and you and us and the flames of stars. We are All.

Then from that I understood, if I hurt you, I hurt me as we are part of each other.

I understood this into and from the core of my being. Surely we All understand this? It seems we mostly do not or we would cherish one another.

As a 40-year practitioner of a meditation technique grounded in the Vedas, I tend to separate the organizational imperatives of religious bureaucrats and their believers from "religion" (a word whose derivation comes from a root meaning "to bind back"). My daily practice binds me back to a subjective self which is not distinct from the "system" it is connected to - "I AM that." Identification with the small "I" ego is overshadowed by a sense of connectedness to the whole.

From this perspective, the "original sin" is identifying oneself as separate from God ("the whole"). Hinduism is quite confusing to me, a Westerner grounded in monotheistic traditions - but Gutting and Ganeri's discussion clarified what seems true to me - that as long as Hinduism (or, indeed, any religion not bound by the sclerosis of bureaucracy), views itself as a heuristic designed to help human understanding and appreciation of the unity of the small self and the whole, it will serve the ends for which it arose.

I had a case a few years ago that had to be reviewed by a "clinician". The clinician turned out to be a former student of mine, one of the poorest in my class. We both recognized each other on the phone.

The course she took with me was on substance abuse, and the patient was a substance abuser. I have 20+ years experience and she just graduated. I taught her just a year ago. She almost denied the claim because I didn't follow her protocol exactly. It was a step-by-step cookbook protocol, and I assessed this patient deviated from the standard case (it was a "dual diagnosis" case) but I was expected to follow all the steps anyway. After much time we reached an "agreement" and the treatment was tentatively accepted. Like Dr.Ofri who wondered about her own blood pressure, I felt like having a drink after this hour conversation!
Great shots. Marty has a really nice eye. These are awesome.

Diana,

Rightly so! They should be paying us for saving our money in their banks!
